TONIGHT ON THE 
      CBS EVENING NEWS Here's an early 
      look at what we are working on for tonight's broadcast of the CBS EVENING 
      NEWS from Anchor and Managing Editor Katie Couric... Hi 
      everyone, I’ll be anchoring tonight’s broadcast from North 
      Carolina, home of Duke University, where the sensational case of three 
      lacrosse players accused of sexual assault has unfolded. Now comes 
      redemption for the accused former college students, Reade Seligmann, David 
      Evans and Collin Finnerty. Prosecutors have decided to drop all criminal 
      charges against the young men, saying the athletes were victims of a 
      “tragic rush to accuse” by District Attorney Mike Nifong – who himself is 
      now under scrutiny. I’ll have that story and my colleagues will be 
      with me in North Carolina covering all the angles. The rape 
      accusation last spring has had widespread ramifications --- it has stoked 
      racial tensions in the Raleigh-Durham community, scarred three families 
      and tarnished the reputation of one of the country’s top universities --- 
      but, as Bob Orr will report, the legal case really was no case at 
      all. Despite that, the parents of the three accused men, who are 
      now 20, 21 and 24 years old, spent an estimated $3.5 million on lawyers. 
      All three are now vindicated, but are still victims. Byron Pitts 
      will take a look at how the accusation has changed the lives of the 
      accused young men and will tell us where they are now. Another 
      reputation tarnished by the accusations was that of one of the country’s 
      top higher education institutions: Duke University. Kelly Wallace 
      will take a look at the media glare that focused on Duke and its lacrosse 
      team for the past year and assess the impact of the accusation on the 
      campus and community. And then we’ll turn to the controversy over 
      on-air comments made by Don Imus about the Rutgers women’s basketball 
      team. The radio host was suspended for two weeks after making the remarks, 
      but it is yet to be seen whether he will stay in his position. But how 
      much is he worth to his broadcasters and advertisers? Anthony Mason 
      will have the story. Finally, I sat down with the family of 
      Reid Seligmann, one of the accused Duke lacrosse players. I’ll 
      share our conversation with you tonight. I hope you’ll join 
      us. Katie For more on two of the stories noted above, 
      please click on the following links: All Duke Lacrosse 
      Charges Dropped Click Here Two Major Sponsors 
      Drop Imus Click Here Here's an early look 
      at one of the stories we are working on for Thursday's broadcast of the 
      CBS Evening News: NATO forces in Afghanistan have launched their 
      spring offensive. Lara Logan is with them during a fierce assault on a 
      major Taliban stronghold. That story, and MUCH more, Thursday on the CBS 
      Evening News. If you would like more information on any of these 
      stories or the broadcast, please click on the following address and e-mail 
      us: evening@cbsnews.com 

TONIGHT ON DAVID LETTERMAN Join Dave tonight on 
      The Late Show with actor Alec Baldwin 
      AND Debbie Parkhurst and her dog, Toby, who performed the Heimlich 
      Maneuver on her… Plus, musical guests LCD Soundsystem! 

THURSDAY MORNING ON THE EARLY SHOW Hannah Storm, 
      Julie Chen, and Russ Mitchell anchor THE EARLY 
      SHOW from New York. Harry Smith will 
      anchor from Raleigh, NC. Dave Price will bring us the weather. 
      Along with the top news of the day, we will also have the 
      following stories: ARCOXIA: BEFORE THE FDA: On 
      Thursday, the Food and Drug Administration will hold a meeting at which 
      non-agency arthritis experts are expected to vote on whether the drug 
      Arcoxia should be approved. Arcoxia, a pain-relieving drug in the same 
      class of the more familiar Vioxx and Bextra, could be approved for use in 
      patients with arthritis. If approved, Arcoxia would be the first in the 
      same class of drugs as Vioxx and Bextra to gain United States approval 
      since those drugs were pulled from the market after showing links to heart 
      attack and stroke in 2004 and 2005. The agency is not required to follow 
      the panel's recommendation, though it often does. We’ll have details 
      Thursday morning. MONEY MATTERS: LAST MINUTE TAX TIPS: With 
      the dreaded April 17th deadline looming, what can you do to keep Uncle Sam 
      happy? Before you file your tax returns, we’ll have important tax tips you 
      won’t want to miss. So how can you avoid paying outrageous fees? If you 
      don’t follow the rules, you could lose your refund. Our financial expert 
      Ray Martin will join us to help you maximize your savings. 
      DAVE’S ALL ACCESS HIGHLIGHTS: Amazingly, it's been 
      two weeks since we wrapped up our latest series of All Access 
      travels around the world. We had so many amazing adventures on the road 
      over the past two months that it was impossible to show you everything 
      that happened along the way. So we decided to take a look at some of the 
      funnier moments of our All Access trips that you may not have seen 
      yet. We’ll have all the highlights… and the lowlights, Thursday morning! 
      YOUNG AT HEART: BOOMERS AND BUSINESS: While boomers are 
      reaching what some say is the better part of their lives. So how common is 
      it for boomers to start their own businesses? The answer may surprise you. 
      More and more, boomers are becoming successful entrepreneurs. Thursday 
      morning, we’ll have some tips on how an eye for possibility and a take 
      charge attitude can achieve business gold. Nancy Perry Graham, Deputy 
      Editor AARP The Magazine, will join us with her advice. 
      ROSE MCGOWAN ON GRINDHOUSE: Actress Rose McGowan 
      made a name for herself in dark teen comedies such as Scream and 
      Jawbreaker. She then starred in the bewitching Charmed for 
      five years, playing Paige Matthews on the show about three sisters 
      battling the forces of evil. Now, McGowan stars in Grindhouse, a 
      double-bill of thrillers that pays homage to its dual filmmakers' favorite 
      exploitation films. In Quentin Tarantino’s slasher film, Death 
      Proof, the killer pursues his targets with a vehicle rather than with 
      a knife. Robert Rodriguez contributes Planet Terror, in which he 
      explores an alien world similar to ours. The combination of the two films 
      results in an action-packed film unlike anything you have seen before. 
      McGowan plays Pam in Death Proof and Cherry in Planet 
      Terror. She will join us Thursday morning to talk about her experience 
      during the project and her love of the finished product. 
      WILLIAMS SONOMA CREPES: Many people love a certain French 
      dish but find it intimidating to make at home. It is the crepe. Americans 
      think of the crepe as a "thin" pancake. . . but as it turns out, it is an 
      incredibly versatile foundation for both sweet and savory flavors. So how 
      can you wow your breakfast guests with a crepe that is surprisingly easy 
      to prepare? Cookbook author Tori Ritchie will join us to demystify this 
      delicious treat so that we can easily enjoy it at home. If you 
      would like more information on any of these stories or the broadcast, 
      please click on the following address and e-mail us: earlyshow@cbs.com
